awd_titl_txt: Virtual Ice Explorer: Immersively Experiencing Changing Glacial Landscapes
awd_abstract_narration:
Glaciers around the world are undergoing dramatic changes. Many people, however, have a limited understanding of the scope of these changes because they are geographically distant and difficult to visualize. Although both digital learning tools and online scientific data repositories have greatly expanded over the last decade, there is currently no interface that brings the two together in a way that allows the public to explore these rapidly changing glacial environments. Therefore, to both improve public understanding and provide greater access to already existing resources, the project team will develop the Virtual Ice Explorer to encourage informal learning about glacial environments. This web application will feature an immersive virtual environment and display a suite of environmental data for an array of Earth's glacial systems. An interactive globe will allow users to select from a collection of sites ranging from polar regions to tropical latitudes. Each featured site will offer users an opportunity to interact with (1) a 3D rendering of the landscape; (2) a local map of the site; (3) historical and contemporary photographs of the site; (4) background information text describing the location, past research, and climate impacts; and (5) available environmental data. One of the most original features of the application will be its realistic, immersive 3D rendering of glacial landscapes by combining very high-resolution digital elevation models and satellite imagery with the application's built-in capabilities for immersive virtual environments. Although immersive environments often require expensive equipment, we are maximizing accessibility by developing the Virtual Ice Explorer to run in a web browser and function across various devices. Thus, the application will be available to anyone with internet access, and they can explore at their own pace. 

As part of the successful development of Virtual Ice Explorer, the project team will create a platform for digital elevation models to be visualized and explored in 3D by users within the web application; curate digital elevation models, maps, images, text, and environmental data for inclusion in the web application for up to 11 geographically diverse glaciers/glacial landscapes; iteratively user-test the web application with project partners; and design the architecture of the system to readily scale to a larger collection of glaciers/glacial landscapes. To extend dissemination of the final products, the team has partnered with the U.S. Geologic Survey to showcase four benchmark glaciers in their long-term Glaciers and Climate project. In addition to improving understanding of glacier systems in informal learning environments, the project team will explore applications for spatial learning, employment of 3D environments for educational interventions, and use of Virtual Ice Explorer in formal learning environments.  This project is funded by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program, which seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments. This includes providing multiple pathways for broadening access to and engagement in STEM learning experiences, advancing innovative research on and assessment of STEM learning in informal environments, and developing understandings of deeper learning by participants. The project also has support from the Office of Polar Programs.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

The project created Virtual Ice Explorer, an interactive web-based tool with tours of nine icy landscapes, including ice sheets, glaciers, and sea ice. Variations on three tours were created with additional interactive features, including puzzles and scavenger hunts, to promote greater engagement during exploration and retention of information following exploration. The team relied on high-resolution photospheres that load relatively quickly, rather than 360 videos that demand significant bandwidth. Combined with use of code that runs on any web browser and placement of larger media content on support platforms, users can navigate landscapes even with an older device or a modest internet connection. All the virtual tours readily operate on three platforms - desktops/laptops, tablets/smartphones, and VR headsets. Virtual Ice Explorer is available at https://virtualice.byrd.osu.edu/. 

The project also refined a workflow to build virtual tours using a combination of off-the-shelf hardware and software, therefore making it possible for research teams to create their own outreach products. In addition to readily-available, highly-dependable, and low-cost GoPro cameras for capturing field footage, the team deployed 3DVista software, a tool developed and optimized for the real-estate community. These tools are commonly used by the public, videographers, outdoor enthusiasts, and gamers and likely to be supported over the long term (in many cases with subsequent software packages or upgrades). By avoiding complex, expensive, and bespoke hardware and software solutions, the team simplified tour maintenance and incentivized future tour development. A "How-To" site describing the workflow, as well as the hardware and software that the team used, is available at https://u.osu.edu/virtualice/tutorials/. 

The project team found it essential to partner with field researchers who know each landscape to develop a compelling narrative to highlight and to populate the tour with relevant, site-specific content (for example photographs, video, text, graphs). Narratives and content highlighted landscapes, geosciences processes, research, and researchers in unique ways within each tour. To streamline the collaboration process with field researchers, the project team created digital templates to allow storyboards to be crafted, content to be populated and feedback to be exchanged while co-designing tours. Prior tours also served as exemplars of what was possible.

The team found that digital elevation models draped with satellite imagery were currently not of sufficient quality and availability to be easily transformed into virtual landscapes for exploration by the general public. Furthermore, tours of landscapes devoid of trees and buildings needed to include some recognizable features, such as people, tents, or vehicles, to be relatable to users. User testing was disrupted during the pandemic, including limited use with the general public in person and no ability to test with VR headsets.

 

Broader Impacts:

All of the content of the virtual tours is available on computer, tablet, smartphone, and VR headset with a modest internet connection. While a VR headset makes the tours more immersive, it is not necessary for exploration. The team worked with our collaborators to deploy the tours in creative ways beyond self-exploration during the pandemic, including as part of virtual classroom visits by informal educators and live guided tours by polar researchers. Beyond collaborating with nine research teams or agencies to create virtual tours for icy landscapes, the team worked with a diverse range of professionals to create a series of laboratory tours at Ohio State University (https://virtualice.byrd.osu.edu/osu-tours.html) and advise other field research teams on how to use our methodology to create their own tours for education and outreach efforts. Another spinoff included creating Virtual Rock Boxes (https://byrd.osu.edu/virtual-rock-box).

Five undergraduate students were trained as part of the project, including majors in Earth sciences, biology, computer science, data analytics, and geographic information systems. Of these students, four have created posters sharing their work, three have written articles, and two have had their article published. The team's workflow and collaborations with research teams was highlighted in an article published in EOS, available at https://eos.org/science-updates/virtual-tours-through-the-ice-using-everyday-tools.
